title: Lego Drag Racer
description: Our group built a Lego Drag Racer that placed 1st in our class competition for the fastest to cross the finish line, analyizing factors like wheel size, gear ratios, and motor quantities and modeling the performance of different car configuations using a MATLAB simulation to optimize our drag racer.

timeline.heading: Investigating Wheel Size
timeline.description: After building our test rig, we found the top speeds for 4 different wheel sizes (68.8mm, 56mm, 43.2mm, 22.2mm) by running the car for 5 seconds and measuring the distance it travelled and time it took. We compared that to the theoretical top speeds, found using the formula (2 * pi * radius * rpm) in Google Sheets with the formulas feature to make data processing easier. We found that cars with larger wheels travel faster than ones with smaller wheels.

timeline.heading: Investigating Gear Ratios
timeline.description: We tested 4 different gear ratios (8:40, 24:40, 8:24 x 24:40, 24:40 x 8:40) by attaching a Vernier Motion Sensor Cart to generate a V-T graph, which we analyzed to find the top speed (max) and acceleration (slope). We compared that to the theoretical top speeds for each car, calculated using the equation (rpm x ratio x 2 * pi * top speed). We found that larger gear ratios have slower acceleration and larger top speeds, while a smaller gear ratio have the opposite effect.

timeline.heading: Investigating Motors
timeline.description: We tried adding another motor to our design in the back, however the car struggled to move. We believed the additional weight and width added to the back of the car decreased the efficiency of the motors. In response, we moved the motor to the front to distribute the load and to make the car more structurally stable.

resources.caption: Car with Dual Motors in Back

timeline.heading: Modeling Car Configurations
timeline.description: Using a MATLAB program, we modeled the predicted performance of each car configuration based on the top speeds and accelerations we collected and graphed the data produced on Google Sheets to predict which configuration would reach the end of the 3-foot race track the quickest. The 8:40 gear ratio with 2 motors performed the best, so we decided to use that.

resources.caption: Position v Time Graph for all car versions

timeline.heading: Race Day #1
timeline.description: We finally got to race our car against the other cars our class made. Prior to the race, we tested our car on the track for four trials and found that our car reached the end in 1.63 seconds. After a close race, we placed 2nd / 6th in our class.

timeline.heading: Improvements
timeline.description: Since the winning car had the same gear ratio and motors, we thought our car was slightly too heavy. To address this, we removed one of the front wheels and moved the other wheel to the center to reduce weight.

timeline.heading: Race Day #2
timeline.description: For this race, the race track was 8 feet long instead of the 3 feet of the previous race. We did 4 trials with our car prior to the tournament, averaging 3.68 seconds. We raced again with our class, where we finally secured a victory!

timeline.heading: Final Thoughts
timeline.description: This project was a sucesss as we successfully built, optimized, and raced a Lego EV3 drag racer. Overall, I learned a lot from this project, like the effect of wheel sizes, gear ratios, and motors on performance. I also improved my collaboration and problem solving skills. If we had to do this project again, I might use bigger wheels and test more gear ratios that are not too high or low to find a gear ratio that performs better. I might try using the new Spike bot system as they are lighter than the Ev3 system. I also might test changing other factors of the car, like the shape of the body or more powerful motors.
